TEXT.English: The value of computers increases sharply when they can be used to send information by remote access over long distances. An isolated computer is just a machine for doing calculations and controlling fixed installations. A computer network can coordinate the activities of a large organization, give all members of the group access to a single central database, or allow scattered groups of people to interact in ways limited only by the power of their computers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Early computer networks were piggybacked onto the existing infrastructure of the telephone system, and made use of simple communication protocols devised by computer scientists and enthusiasts. Over time, the complexity of networks has increased, as has the body of technical literature and specialist skills devoted to designing, building, and maintaining them. Today, most of the world's computer networks flow together seamlessly into the Internet, a world-spanning system that allows nearly anyone on Earth to communicate with anyone else, given computer access.
TEXT.Chinese: 当计算机可以通过远程访问发送信息时，其价值急剧增加。一台孤立的计算机只是一台进行计算和控制固定装置的机器。一个计算机网络可以协调一个大型组织的活动，让所有成员都能访问一个中央数据库，或者允许分散的人群以仅受计算机功率限制的方式进行交互。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]早期的计算机网络被承载在电话系统的现有基础设施上，并利用计算机科学家和发烧友设计的简单通信协议。随着时间的推移，网络的复杂性增加了，专门设计、构建和维护网络的技术文献和专业技能也在增加。今天，世界上大多数的计算机网络无缝地汇合到互联网上，这是一个跨越世界的系统，只要有计算机接入，几乎地球上的任何人都可以与其他人通信。

TEXT.English: Psychology is the science of behavior and mind, embracing all aspects of conscious and unconscious experience as well as thought. It is an academic discipline and a social science which seeks to understand individuals and groups by establishing general principles and researching specific cases.[PARAGRAPH:2]In this field, a professional practitioner or researcher is called a psychologist and can be classified as a social, behavioral, or cognitive scientist. Psychologists attempt to understand the role of mental functions in individual and social behavior, while also exploring the physiological and biological processes that underlie cognitive functions and behaviors.[PARAGRAPH:2]Psychologists explore behavior and mental processes, including perception, cognition, attention, emotion (affect), intelligence, phenomenology, motivation (conation), brain functioning, and personality. This extends to interaction between people, such as interpersonal relationships, including psychological resilience, family resilience, and other areas. Psychologists of diverse orientations also consider the unconscious mind.[PARAGRAPH:2]Psychologists employ empirical methods to infer causal and correlational relationships between psychosocial variables. In addition, or in opposition, to employing empirical and deductive methods, some-especially clinical and counseling psychologists-at times rely upon symbolic interpretation and other inductive techniques. Psychology has been described as a "hub science", with psychological findings linking to research and perspectives from the social sciences, natural sciences, medicine, humanities, and philosophy.
TEXT.Chinese: 心理学是行为和心理的科学，包括有意识和无意识经验以及思想的所有方面。它是一门通过建立一般原则和研究具体案例来理解个人和群体的学科和社会科学。[第2段]在这一领域中，专业的实践者或研究者被称为心理学家，可以被分为社会科学家、行为科学家或认知科学家。心理学家试图理解心理功能在个体和社会行为中的作用，同时也探索认知功能和行为的生理和生物学过程。[段落：2 ]心理学家探索行为和心理过程，包括感知、认知、注意、情感（情感），智力，现象学，动机，大脑功能和个性。这延伸到人与人之间的互动，如人际关系，包括心理弹性、家庭弹性等领域。不同取向的心理学家也考虑无意识心理。[段落：2 ]心理学家使用经验方法来推断心理社会变量之间的因果关系和相关关系。除此之外，或者与之相反，一些心理学家，特别是临床和心理咨询心理学家，有时依赖于符号解释和其他归纳方法。心理学被描述为一门“中心科学”，心理学的发现与社会科学、自然科学、医学、人文科学和哲学的研究和观点相联系。

TEXT.English: "Two cities have been formed by two loves: the earthly by the love of self; the heavenly by the love of God."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Augustine of Hippo, The City of God
TEXT.Chinese: “两个城市是由两种爱构成的：人间的爱，上帝的爱。”（段落：2）――河马，上帝之城的奥古斯丁。

TEXT.English: After the establishment of the scientific method, the next step in the scientific revolution was the development of accurate and reliable means of measurement. Refinements and developments of scientific instruments such as the microscope or thermometer were essential for the subsequent advances in scientific fields like biology or chemistry.[PARAGRAPH:2]Measurement was also very important during the ongoing exploration of the world. Accurate navigation was finally possible with the invention of accurate mechanical clocks. And international effort was undertaken to measure as many aspects of the natural world as possible. This led to the development of an international system for units of measurement, the metric system.
TEXT.Chinese: 科学方法建立后，科学革命的下一步是发展准确可靠的测量手段。科学仪器如显微镜或温度计的改进和发展对于科学或生物学等领域的后续进展至关重要。[段落：2 ]在进行世界探索期间，测量也是非常重要的。随着精密机械钟的发明，精确导航终于成为可能。国际社会也在尽可能多地测量自然世界的各个方面。这导致了国际计量单位制的发展，即公制。

TEXT.English: "The matter lies before the eyes of all; everybody sees it, touches it, loves it, but knows it not."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Lucas Jennis, The Hermetic Library
TEXT.Chinese: “这件事就在所有人的眼前，每个人都看到它，触摸它，爱它，但不知道它。”[段落：2 ] - Lucas Jennis，密闭图书馆

TEXT.English: "Dogma" refers to a firmly established body of beliefs and opinions, generally associated with religion and laid out by respected theologians within the faith. Within that religion, the dogma is considered authoritative and final - it may be clarified or expanded upon, but not contradicted. To call the basic facts of the dogma into question is, by definition, to leave the religion for some other path which may be deemed heretical.[PARAGRAPH:2]Different religions have different core bodies of dogma, which usually focus on key points of doctrine that the religious leaders consider to be of extreme importance. In Christianity, the concept of salvation through faith in Christ is a matter of dogma, although the details of how this salvation may best be achieved can vary. In Islam, it is a point of dogma that Muhammed was the last of the divinely inspired prophets.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dogma is particularly important to organized religions, since it serves to define the limits of what can and cannot be accepted as part of the faith. Learning the basic principles outlined by the dogma is considered the universal foundation of education within the religious tradition, and among the scholarly figures of the religion, all knowledge and all philosophy is likely to be interpreted through the dogma's lens. Groups which defy dogma are often forced to recant, removed from positions of official responsibility, and even violently persecuted until they rejoin the fold, flee, or die.[PARAGRAPH:2]The concept of points of dogma that a society will not tolerate violation of is not unique to religion. Many totalitarian societies feature secular political 'dogma', de facto or de jure, which cannot be violated without the hostile attentions of the state.
TEXT.Chinese: “教条”是指一个牢固确立的信仰和意见体系，通常与宗教有关，并由信仰内受尊敬的神学家提出。在这一宗教中，教条被认为是权威的和最终的――它可以被澄清或扩展，但不矛盾。把教条的基本事实称为问题是，将宗教留给其他可能被视为异端的路径。[段落：2 ]不同的宗教有不同的教义核心体，通常集中在宗教领袖认为极为重要的教义的要点上。在基督教中，通过对基督的信仰而得救的概念是一个教条问题，尽管如何最好地实现这种得救的细节可能会有所不同。在Islam，教条是一个教条，Muhammed是神圣的先知中的最后一位。[段落：2 ]教条对于有组织的宗教来说特别重要，因为它可以定义什么是可以接受的，什么是不能接受的，这是信仰的一部分。学习教条所概括的基本原则被认为是宗教传统中教育的普遍基础，在宗教的学术人物中，所有的知识和哲学都可能通过教条的镜头来解释。反对教条的群体往往被迫放弃，从官方责任的立场上撤除，甚至迫害，直到他们重新加入，逃跑，或死亡。[段落：2 ]一个社会不能容忍违反教义的教条的概念不是宗教独有的。许多极权主义社会的特点是世俗的政治“教条”，事实上或法律上，如果没有国家的敌对关注，这些教条是不能被违反的。

TEXT.English: Superconductivity is a phenomenon of exactly zero electrical resistance and expulsion of magnetic flux fields occurring in certain materials, called superconductors, when cooled below a characteristic critical temperature. It was discovered by Dutch physicist Heike Kamerlingh Onnes on April 8, 1911, in Leiden. Like ferromagnetism and atomic spectral lines, superconductivity is a quantum mechanical phenomenon. It is characterized by the Meissner effect, the complete ejection of magnetic field lines from the interior of the superconductor as it transitions into the superconducting state. The occurrence of the Meissner effect indicates that superconductivity cannot be understood simply as the idealization of perfect conductivity in classical physics.[PARAGRAPH:2]The electrical resistance of a metallic conductor decreases gradually as temperature is lowered. In ordinary conductors, such as copper or silver, this decrease is limited by impurities and other defects. Even near absolute zero, a real sample of a normal conductor shows some resistance. In a superconductor; the resistance drops abruptly to zero when the material is cooled below its critical temperature. An electric current flowing through a loop of superconducting wire can persist indefinitely with no power source.[PARAGRAPH:2]Superconducting magnets are some of the most powerful electromagnets known. They are used in MRI/NMR machines, mass spectrometers, the beam-steering magnets used in particle accelerators and plasma confining magnets in some tokamaks. They can also be used for magnetic separation, where weakly magnetic particles are extracted from a background of less or non-magnetic particles, as in the pigment industries.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the 1950s and 1960s, superconductors were used to build experimental digital computers using cryotron switches. More recently, superconductors have been used to make digital circuits based on rapid single flux quantum technology and RF and microwave filters for mobile phone base stations.

TEXT.English: Heritage is that which, having been created by our ancestors, is given to us because our ancestors willed that it be given to us. The concept of heritage and similar words with the same root such as "inheritance" and "heredity" are fundamental to the human self-image. Nearly everyone feels affectionate bonds to both their ancestors and their descendants. As a result, there is a near-universal desire to make sure that one's descendants inherit the virtues, resources, and opportunities that made one's own successes possible. Conversely, there is a near-universal belief that one is entitled to practice the traditions, use the assets, and partake of the opportunities that one's ancestors enjoyed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]More broadly, heritage can refer to the collective legacy left behind by the ancestral generations of an entire town, nation, culture, or civilization. This heritage can be material (natural resources cultivated and preserved by past generations), economic (control over property owned by ancestors), aesthetic (works of art that have endured through multiple generations), cultural (practices that protected or enriched the society in the past), or spiritual (the presumed supernatural protection of ancestral spirits, and the idea of following "the faith of one's fathers" as a gesture of unity with that which came before and that which will come in the future.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]How to efficiently preserve one's heritage, to obtain as large a share of its rewards as possible, while passing it down to the next generation in turn, is a preoccupation of most humans and most human societies. Individuals do this with legal procedures such as wills or through the practices of childrearing (intended to instill traditional virtues in the young). Nations fund museums and preservation projects, make laws regarding cultural practices, and sometimes even go to war for the sake of preserving their heritage from that which they perceive to threaten it.
TEXT.Chinese: 遗产是由我们的祖先创造的，由于我们的祖先的意愿而给予我们的。传承的概念和“传承”、“遗传”等具有相同根源的相似词语是人类自我形象的基础。几乎每个人都对自己的祖先和后代有着深情的纽带。因此，人们有一种近乎普遍的愿望，希望确保自己的后代继承使自己成功成为可能的美德、资源和机会。相反，有一种近乎普遍的信仰，认为一个人有权实践传统，使用资产，并分享祖先享有的机会。[新线][新线]更广泛地说，遗产是指整个城镇、民族、文化或文明的祖辈留下的集体遗产。这种遗产可以是物质的（过去几代人培育和保存的自然资源）、经济的（对祖先财产的控制）、美学的（经过几代人的艺术作品）、文化的（过去保护或丰富社会的实践）或精神的（假定的超自然保护祖先的精神，以及遵循“祖先的信仰”的理念，以此作为一种与过去和未来的统一的姿态。[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]如何有效地保护自己的遗产，获得尽可能多的回报，同时将其传给下一代，是大多数人类和大多数人类社会所关注的问题。个人通过法律程序如遗嘱或育儿实践（旨在向年轻人灌输传统美德）做到这一点。各国为博物馆和保护项目提供资金，制定有关文化习俗的法律，有时甚至为了保护自己的遗产免受威胁而发动战争。

TEXT.English: Patronage is the practice of a wealthy or powerful individual choosing to support an artist, charitable organization, scholar, or other worthy cause. This support generally takes the form of donations of money or the exercise of political influence. Patronage is vital to the survival of the arts, even in the modern era when artists can at least occasionally rely on state grants to support their activities - which arguably is itself a form of patronage.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the medieval and renaissance eras, in particular, the patronage of aristocrats, wealthy merchants, and even kings and emperors had major consequences for the evolution of human knowledge. Emperors and merchant princes funded great voyages of discovery that traveled across continents. Kings and queens adopted radical philosophers into their courts, giving the philosophers the security they needed to publish ideas about human nature, ethics, and political theory.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]从古代开始，艺术赞助在艺术史上占有重要地位。在中世纪和文艺复兴时期的欧洲，人们对它的了解最为详细，但在封建的日本、传统的东南亚王国和其他地方，艺术赞助往往出现在皇室或皇室制度和贵族统治一个社会并控制着大量资源的地方。塞缪尔・强森把一个守护神定义为“一个不关心一个在水中挣扎的人的人，当他到达地面时，用他来帮助他”。[段落：2 ]统治者、贵族和非常富有的人利用艺术的赞助来支持他们的政治野心、社会地位和声望。也就是说，赞助商。一些语言仍然使用mecenate一词，源于Gaius Maecenas的名字，Gaius Maecenas是罗马皇帝奥古斯都慷慨的朋友和顾问。一些赞助人，比如佛罗伦萨的美第奇，利用艺术赞助人来“净化”那些被认为是通过高利贷获得的不义之财。艺术赞助在宗教艺术创作中尤为重要。罗马天主教和后来的新教团体赞助艺术和建筑，如教堂、教堂、绘画、雕塑和手工艺品。[段：2 ]赞助艺术家和艺术作品是赞助制度中最著名的方面，其他学科也受益于赞助，包括那些人。研究自然哲学（前现代科学），音乐家，作家，哲学家，炼金术士，占星家和其他学者。像克雷蒂安・德特洛耶斯、列奥纳多・达芬奇和米开朗基罗、威廉・莎士比亚和本・琼森这样多样而重要的艺术家，都寻求并获得了贵族或教会赞助人的支持。莫扎特和贝多芬等人物也在一定程度上参与了这一体系；直到19世纪资产阶级和资本主义社会形式的兴起，欧洲文化才从其赞助体系转移到更为公开支持的博物馆、剧院、大众观众和大众消费体系，这是人们所熟悉的当代世界。[段落：2 ]这种系统继续在许多艺术领域中延续。虽然赞助商的性质已经从教堂转变为慈善基金会，从贵族到富豪，“赞助”一词在政治上比政治上具有更为中性的内涵。它可能只是指艺术家的直接支持（通常是财政支持），例如通过资助。20世纪下半叶，赞助人研究的学术分支学科开始演变，认识到赞助人现象在前几个世纪的文化生活中所起的重要作用，而且常常被忽视。

TEXT.English: Property refers to the concept that a certain object, idea, or place is solely under the authority of some specific person or entity, and is not available for the use of others without the consent of that 'owner.' The most basic Neolithic societies known to us usually have concepts of individual ownership of certain items, such as tools and caches of food. This is often combined with widespread sharing of the goods, usually done for purposes of reinforcing social ties.[PARAGRAPH:2]Such a practice results in very cohesive societies. However, such societies often have difficulty organizing their surplus resources to commit to large-scale projects not of immediate use to any one person (such as infrastructure, ceremonial architecture, or military expeditions). Moreover, the system tends to break down in the presence of large numbers of strangers, because it relies on individuals being willing to freely share their belongings with each other. For both these reasons, the rise of cities generally went hand-in-hand with the rise of accumulated property in the hands of social elites, a trend which has persisted throughout recorded history to the present day.
TEXT.Chinese: 财产是指一个特定的物体、观念或场所完全由某个特定的人或实体支配，未经“所有者”的同意，不能供他人使用的概念。我们所知的最基本的新石器时代社会通常都有某些物品的个人所有权的概念，如工具和藏品食物。这通常与广泛的货物共享相结合，通常是为了加强社会联系而进行的。[段落：2 ]这样的做法导致了非常有凝聚力的社会。然而，这些社会往往很难将其剩余资源组织起来，用于任何人都不能立即使用的大型项目（如基础设施、礼仪建筑或军事考察）。此外，该系统往往会在大量陌生人面前崩溃，因为它依赖于个人愿意自由分享自己的物品。由于这两个原因，城市的崛起通常与社会精英手中积累的财产的崛起齐头并进，这一趋势在有史以来一直持续到今天。

TEXT.English: The scholarly method or scholarship is the body of principles and practices used by scholars to make their claims about the world as valid and trustworthy as possible, and to make them known to the scholarly public. It is the methods that systemically advance the teaching, research, and practice of a given scholarly or academic field of study through rigorous inquiry. Scholarship is noted by its significance to its particular profession, and is creative, can be documented, can be replicated or elaborated, and can be and is peer-reviewed through various methods.[PARAGRAPH:2]Originally started to reconcile the philosophy of the ancient classical philosophers with medieval theology, scholasticism is not a philosophy or theology in itself but a tool and method for learning which places emphasis on dialectical reasoning. The primary purpose of scholasticism is to find the answer to a question or to resolve a contradiction. It was once well known for its application in medieval theology but was eventually applied to classical philosophy and many other fields of study.
TEXT.Chinese: 学术方法或学术是学者们用以使他们对世界的主张尽可能有效和可信，并使他们为学术公众所知的原则和实践。它是通过严格的调查，系统地推进某一学术或学术领域的教学、研究和实践的方法。奖学金是以其对特定职业的重要性而著称的，它具有创造性、可记录性、可复制性或可阐述性，可以通过各种方法进行同行评议。[段：2 ]最初开始调和古代古典哲学家的哲学与中世纪神学，经院哲学本身不是一种哲学或神学，而是一种强调辩证推理的学习工具和方法。经院哲学的主要目的是找到问题的答案或解决矛盾。它曾因在中世纪神学中的应用而闻名，但最终应用于古典哲学和许多其他研究领域。

TEXT.English: As computer technology advances its capabilities at a geometric rate, the ability of computer software to emulate intelligent decisions grows. Automation first replaces routine, mundane labor on assembly lines, then an increasing share of service and office jobs. As the process continues, it seems likely that computers will become able to sustain true intelligence, at least for a pragmatic definition of the term.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some predict that the creation of the first artificial intelligences will lead to a 'singularity' beyond which we lose our ability to predict the course of human development: these AIs will rapidly begin to modify and improve themselves until their capabilities are little short of godlike. Others feel that this is an exaggeration of the possibilities. Regardless, artificial intelligence is likely to play a prominent role in the development of human society in the future.
TEXT.Chinese: 随着计算机技术以几何速度提高其能力，计算机软件模拟智能决策的能力也在增长。自动化首先取代了流水线上日常的、平凡的劳动，然后是越来越多的服务和办公室工作。随着这一过程的继续，计算机似乎能够维持真正的智能，至少是对术语的实用定义。[段落：2 ]有人预言，创造第一个人工智能将导致一个“奇点”，我们失去了预测人类发展过程的能力：这些AIS会很快开始自我改造和提升，直到他们的能力有点像上帝。其他人认为这是对可能性的夸大。无论如何，人工智能很可能在未来人类社会的发展中发挥突出的作用。

TEXT.English: A telephone, from the Greek for 'distant voice,' is an device that converts a speaker's voice into electrical impulses, transmits them to a remote receiver, permits the speaker to receive other similar signals, and converts them back into voice. This permits conversations to be had between any two owners of telephones on the same switching network.[PARAGRAPH:2]There is some debate over who invented the telephone. Many individuals were working to design them, with similar tools, throughout the 1860s and '70s. However, it is clear that within a few years of the first commercially successful telephones being created, systems of the devices were beginning to connect distant cities. The telephone allowed infinitely faster and richer exchanges of information than any pre-19th century mode of communication, and had great advantages compared to the slightly earlier telegraph as well.[PARAGRAPH:2]Early telephone technology was highly diverse, but standardized as the 20th century began and as telephone systems became increasingly networked. It was found that while a specific telephone line from one place to another was valuable, a network permitting every user to call every other user was exponentially more valuable. Elaborate systems of manually operated "switchboards" emerged, allowing connections to be made at will between different telephones on the network.[PARAGRAPH:2]Networks grew larger and the individual telephones grew more compact and user-friendly throughout the early and mid-20th centuries. After the computer revolution began in the 1950s and '60s, automated switching took the place of manually operated systems, touch-tone dialing replaced rotary phones, and long distance calls became a cheaper and more common activity connecting the world together.[PARAGRAPH:2]The next great advance, mobile telephony, came in the 1970s and '80s, reaching maturity around the turn of the millenium. Cellular networks of transceiver towers make it possible for every citizen to carry a miniaturized wireless telephone, permitting near-instant communication throughout the world. Over the past decade, this technology has been further refined and combined with further miniaturization, allowing a single handheld device to serve as telephone, camera, appointment book, a portable device for audiovisual entertainment, and a gaming platform.
TEXT.Chinese: 希腊语中的电话是一种装置，可以将说话人的声音转换成电脉冲，传送到远程接收器，允许说话人接收其他类似的信号，并将其转换成声音。这允许在同一个交换网络上的两个电话拥有者之间进行对话。[段：2 ]关于谁发明了电话有一些争论。在整个19世纪60年代和70年代，许多人都在用类似的工具设计它们，然而，很明显，在第一部商业上成功的电话问世的几年内，这些设备的系统开始连接遥远的城市。电话比任何19世纪前的通信模式都允许了无限快和更丰富的信息交换，并且与稍早的电报相比也有很大的优势。[段：2 ]早期电话技术高度多样化，但随着二十世纪开始标准化，电话系统也越来越多。联网。研究发现，虽然从一个地方到另一个地方的特定电话线是有价值的，但允许每个用户呼叫每个其他用户的网络却是指数级的更有价值。精心设计的手动操作的“配电盘”系统，允许在网络上的不同电话之间随意连接。[段：2 ]网络越来越大，各个电话在20世纪初和中期都变得更加紧凑和用户友好。在20世纪50年代和60年代计算机革命开始后，自动交换取代了手动操作系统，用按键拨号代替了旋转电话，长途电话成为连接世界的一种更廉价、更普遍的活动。[第2段]下一个伟大的进步，移动电话，出现在20世纪70年代和80年代，在世纪之交达到成熟。无线发射塔的蜂窝网络使每个公民都有可能携带一部小型无线电话，从而在全世界实现近即时通信。在过去的十年中，这项技术得到了进一步的改进，并与进一步的小型化相结合，使得单个手持设备可以用作电话、照相机、预约簿、用于视听娱乐的便携式设备和游戏平台。

TEXT.English: Metallurgy is the study of the properties of metals and the methods used to separate metal deposits from metal-bearing ores. Through the course of history, artisans have switched the materials from which they constructed weapons and tools to harder, more durable metals as they were discovered. Constant improvements in metallurgy led to the discovery of new metals and alloys that were stronger, lighter, and cheaper.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the late 19th century, metallurgy was a sophisticated science. The rise of modern chemistry led to the discovery of a vast number of 'new' chemical elements that could be used in alloys, and electric power made it possible to control the conditions under which metals were worked more finely than ever before. Metallurgists developed a vast array of new kinds of steel and other alloys, with different combinations of hardness, flexibility, corrosion-resistance, and other properties. These rapid advances in metallurgy had vast implications for almost every field of engineering.
TEXT.Chinese: 冶金学是研究金属的性质以及从含金属矿石中分离金属矿床的方法。在整个历史过程中，工匠们已经将制造武器和工具的材料转变为发现时更坚硬、更耐用的金属。冶金的不断改进导致了新的金属和合金的发现，这些金属和合金更强大、更轻、更便宜。[段：2 ]到十九世纪下旬，冶金是一门复杂的科学。现代化学的兴起导致了大量可用于合金中的“新”化学元素的发现，而电力使控制金属比以往任何时候都更精细工作的条件成为可能。冶金学家开发了大量新型钢和其他合金，具有不同的硬度、柔韧性、耐腐蚀性和其他性能组合。冶金的这些快速发展对几乎所有的工程领域都有着巨大的影响。

TEXT.English: In the early ancient world, armies mostly consisted of militia and levies that were only raised in the event of war. These armies were usually small enough and the ensuing warfare limited enough to be directly commanded by their political leaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the Roman Republic and later Empire, armies became increasingly professionalised, especially after the Marian reforms. The large extent of the Roman Empire also made it impractical for their leadership to exercise direct control over the military. Similar developments also took place in the Chinese Han dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:2]This development conferred more military and political power to the generals entrusted with military command. While this made armies more professional and successful, it also led to a different distribution of power. In the Roman Empire, generals were often the decisive factor in choosing the next emperor or disposing of an unsuccessful sitting emperor, contributing to the empires instability. In China, competing military warlords ultimately caused the collapse of the Han dynasty.[PARAGRAPH:2]This sort of political power based on military authority paved the way for the idea of nobility in the feudal sense and the system of feudalism in the Middle Ages.
TEXT.Chinese: 在早期的古代世界，军队主要由民兵和征兵组成，只有在战争中才会被征募。这些军队通常是足够小的，随后的战争足够有限，直接由他们的政治领袖指挥。[段：2 ]在罗马共和国和后来的帝国，军队变得越来越专业化，特别是在Marian改革之后。罗马帝国的庞大规模也使得他们的领导层直接控制军队不切实际。中国汉朝也发生了类似的发展。[段落：2 ]这一发展赋予了军事指挥官更多的军事和政治权力。虽然这使军队更加专业和成功，但也导致了不同的权力分配。在罗马帝国，将军往往是选择下一个皇帝或处置一个不成功的在位皇帝的决定性因素，导致帝国的不稳定。在中国，竞争的军阀最终导致了汉朝的崩溃。[段落：2 ]这种基于军事权威的政治权力为封建意义上的贵族思想和中世纪封建制度奠定了基础。

TEXT.English: Smelting is a form of extractive metallurgy; its main use is to produce a base metal from its ore. This includes production of silver, iron, copper and other base metals from their ores. Smelting makes use of heat and a chemical reducing agent to decompose the ore, driving off other elements as gases or slag and leaving just the metal base behind. The reducing agent is commonly a source of carbon such as coke, or in earlier times charcoal.[PARAGRAPH:2]The carbon (or carbon monoxide derived from it) removes oxygen from the ore, leaving behind the elemental metal. The carbon is thus oxidized in two stages, producing first carbon monoxide and then carbon dioxide. As most ores are impure, it is often necessary to use flux, such as limestone, to remove the accompanying rock gangue as slag.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the Old World, the first metals smelted were tin and lead. After tin and lead, the next metal to be smelted appears to have been copper. How the discovery came about is a matter of much debate. Campfires are about 200 °C short of the temperature needed for that, so it has been conjectured that the first smelting of copper may have been achieved in pottery kilns. The development of copper smelting in the Andes, which is believed to have occurred independently of that in the Old World, may have occurred in the same way.[PARAGRAPH:2]The discovery of copper manufacture had a significant impact on the history of the Old World. Metals were hard enough to make weapons that were heavier, stronger, and more resistant to impact-related damage than their wood, bone, or stone equivalents.
TEXT.Chinese: 冶炼是一种萃取冶金，其主要用途是从矿石中生产贱金属，包括从矿石中生产银、铁、铜和其他贱金属。熔炼利用热量和化学还原剂分解矿石，把其他元素如气体或炉渣赶走，只留下金属基。还原剂通常是碳的来源，如焦炭，或在早期的木炭中。〔段落：2〕碳（或来自它的一氧化碳）从矿石中除去氧，留下元素金属。因此，碳被氧化为两个阶段，首先产生一氧化碳，然后产生二氧化碳。由于大多数矿石是不纯的，因此经常需要使用熔剂，如石灰石，以除去伴随的岩石矸石作为矿渣。[段落：2 ]在旧世界，第一金属冶炼的是锡和铅。在锡和铅之后，下一个要熔炼的金属似乎是铜。这个发现是如何产生的，这是一个争论不休的问题。营火的温度比所需的温度低约200摄氏度，因此有人推测，铜的首次熔炼可能是在陶窑中实现的。安第斯山脉的铜冶炼的发展，据信是独立于旧世界发生的，也可能以同样的方式发生。[第2段]铜的发现对旧世界的历史产生了重大影响。金属的硬度足以制造出比木头、骨头或石头更重、更坚固、更能抵抗撞击相关损伤的武器。

TEXT.English: Cybernetics is a term coined by pioneering computer scientist Norbert Wiener, referring to the science of studying control systems, organization, and information flow. This is a relatively new field of research, dating to the mid-20th century. Cyberneticists seek to understand how decisions are made, and how to improve the process using systematic, scientific methods. This is particularly important in the fields of automation and computer programming. Setting up a computer to do a job in a human's place cannot be done unless the computer's programmers and users understand how it is to make the necessary decisions: how the computer 'thinks.' Cybernetics also finds use in management of human beings, because its theories can be applied to the flow of information and decisions up and down a chain of command, among a peer group, or through other social structures.[PARAGRAPH:2]More colloquially, "cybernetics" is often used to refer to advanced automation, or to a mixture of organic and machine technology, particularly in the context of the newly-dawning Information Age. Naturally, this is tied into the research described above - one can hardly design an advanced robot without knowing how to build a decision-making computer.
TEXT.Chinese: 控制论是由计算机先驱诺伯特・维纳（Norbert Wiener）提出的一个术语，指研究控制系统、组织和信息流的科学。这是一个相对较新的研究领域，可以追溯到20世纪中叶。控制论者试图了解决策是如何做出的，以及如何使用系统的、科学的方法来改进过程。这在自动化和计算机编程领域尤为重要。除非计算机的程序员和用户了解如何做出必要的决定：计算机是如何“思考”的，否则无法在人的地方安装计算机来完成工作。控制论也可以用于人的管理，因为它的理论可以应用于一个指挥链、一个同辈群体或其他社会结构中的信息流和决策流程。[第2段]更一般地说，“控制论”经常被用来指先进的自动化，或者是有机和机器技术的混合。尤其是在新信息时代的背景下。很自然，这与上述的研究有关――不知道如何构建决策计算机，就很难设计出先进的机器人。

TEXT.English: Labour unions arose in the 18th and 19th century in response to the poor working conditions brought on by an intense competition for jobs, and the increasing dependence of the working class on their employers created by the move toward industrialization. Early labour unions, formed by skilled labourers in specific fields, met with opposition from both employers and the government. In the 19th century, laws were passed legalizing labour unions, and by the 20th century unions were formed in semi- or unskilled fields such as mining, transportation, and dock working. Binding their interests together and bargaining collectively, labour unions forced factory and business owners to provide better working conditions and economic status for their workers.
TEXT.Chinese: 工会产生于18和19世纪，是为了应对激烈的就业竞争带来的恶劣的工作条件，以及工业化带来的工人阶级对雇主的日益依赖。早期的工会由特定领域的技术工人组成，遭到雇主和政府的反对。19世纪，通过了使工会合法化的法律，到20世纪，在采矿、运输和码头工作等半技术或非技术领域成立了工会。工会将他们的利益捆绑在一起，集体谈判，迫使工厂和企业主为他们的工人提供更好的工作条件和经济地位。

TEXT.English: The field of electronics deals with the practical application and manipulation of electricity and electromagnetic phenomena. The invention of the vacuum tube in the early 20th century marked the beginning of modern electronics. The vacuum tube was capable of amplifying weak radio signals, allowing them to be transmitted over greater distances. Vacuum tubes also allowed music and voice to be superimposed onto radio waves for transmission. The early study of electronics revolutionized a number of fields, especially the field of communications. Because of the vacuum tube, the technology of radio communications was highly developed by World War II. After the war, electronics research continued to advance rapidly. Post-war advances include the earliest examples of digital computers and, eventually, transistors and integrated circuits: miniaturized replacements for the vacuum tube.
TEXT.Chinese: 电子学领域涉及电和电磁现象的实际应用和操作。20世纪初真空管的发明标志着现代电子技术的开始。真空管能够放大微弱的无线电信号，使它们能够传送到更远的距离。真空管还允许音乐和声音叠加到无线电波上进行传输。早期的电子学研究使许多领域发生了革命性的变化，特别是通信领域。由于真空管的存在，无线电通信技术在第二次世界大战中得到了高度发展。战后，电子研究继续快速发展。战后的进步包括最早的数字计算机，以及最终的晶体管和集成电路：真空管的小型化替代品。

TEXT.English: Architecture is the discipline of designing structures with an eye to specific goals; usually aesthetic appeal, but also functional features such as defensibility. The architect's trade blends that of the ordinary engineer and the artist. On the one hand, all great architecture must be durable enough to stand natural forces and the test of time; on the other, it is often expected to be pleasant to live in and to behold.
TEXT.Chinese: 建筑是一门着眼于特定目标设计结构的学科；通常是审美情趣，但也有功能性特征，如防御性。建筑师的职业把普通工程师和艺术家的职业融合在一起。一方面，所有伟大的建筑必须经久耐用，经得起自然力和时间的考验；另一方面，人们通常认为，居住和观赏都是令人愉快的。

TEXT.English: Radar is a method of using radio waves to observe one's surroundings by technological means. Derived from the acronym "RAdio Detection And Ranging," radar permits observation to continue at distances the naked eye cannot reach, in conditions of bad weather and darkness the eye cannot penetrate, with machine-like precision the eye cannot duplicate. It is particularly useful for detecting aircraft at long range, although it can also be used from an aircraft to survey the land, or from a ship to detect another ship at sea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Innovation in radar technology began shortly before the Second World War, with Britain in the lead and other nations such as Germany and the US following close behind. The British capitalized on their advantage and developed the highly effective "Chain Home" system of early warning stations to detect any enemy aircraft trying to attack their island. This proved a very useful defensive asset in resisting the severe German air attacks of 'the Blitz' during late 1940. Combined with other uses of the radio spectrum (such as cunningly mimicking German navigation beacons so that German bombers would get lost in the dark and bomb random wheat fields instead of British cities), Britain used its advantage in radar to wage what Winston Churchill called a "wizards' war" that complemented the air war then being fought.[PARAGRAPH:2]When the tables began to turn in 1943, the Germans too found radar a useful means of defending against British and American air attack, although the sheer mass of the Allied war machine caused their defenses to break down by late 1944. Meanwhile, the Germans' submarine warfare campaign likewise suffered from Allied use of radar to detect submarines; and on the other side of the world, the total lack of effective radar on the part of their allies, the Japanese, played a major role in Japan's defeat in air and naval combat from 1942 on.[PARAGRAPH:2]Radar became far more advanced and developed in the postwar era with the steady rise of electronics technology, especially after the vacuum tube gave way to the integrated circuit. The military continues to make use of radar imaging as the primary means of tracking aircraft, and also employs it to scan the ground from the air. In civilian applications, radar is used to coordinate commercial air traffic to prevent collisions, and is a common, valuable scientific instrument whenever detailed imagery needs to be taken from a distance.
TEXT.Chinese: 雷达是利用无线电波通过技术手段观察周围环境的一种方法。雷达源于“无线电探测和测距”的缩写，允许在恶劣天气和黑暗条件下，眼睛无法穿透肉眼无法到达的距离继续观察，具有机器般的精度，眼睛无法复制。它特别适用于远距离探测飞机，虽然它也可以从飞机上用来探测陆地，也可以从船上探测到另一艘船在海上航行。〔2〕雷达技术的革新在第二次世界大战前不久就开始了。英国领先，德国和美国紧随其后。英国人利用他们的优势，开发了高效的“链家”预警站系统，以侦测任何试图攻击他们岛屿的敌机。事实证明，这是抵抗1940年末德国空袭“闪电战”的一项非常有用的防御手段。再加上无线电频谱的其他用途（比如巧妙地模仿德国导航信标，让德国轰炸机迷失在黑暗中，轰炸随意的麦田，而不是英国城市），英国利用其在雷达上的优势来完成温斯顿邱吉尔所称的“巫师战争”，补充了当时的空战。[段：2 ]当1943的战斗机开始转动时，德国人也发现雷达是抵御英国和美国空袭的有用手段。尽管盟军战争机器的庞大规模导致他们的防御系统在1944年末崩溃。与此同时，德国的潜艇作战也同样受到盟军使用雷达探测潜艇的影响；而在世界的另一边，盟军日本则完全缺乏有效的雷达，从1942起，日本在空战中的失败起到了重要作用。[段：2 ]随着电子技术的稳步崛起，尤其是在真空管进入集成电路之后，雷达在战后时代变得更加先进和发达。军方继续利用雷达成像作为跟踪飞机的主要手段，并利用它从空中扫描地面。在民用应用中，雷达用于协调商业空中交通以防止碰撞，并且在需要从远处拍摄详细图像时，雷达是一种常见的、有价值的科学仪器。

TEXT.English: A ceremony is an event of ritual significance, performed on a special occasion. Even in the earliest societies, religious beliefs were often associated with recurring events that required the performance of ceremonies. These ceremonies could take place in smaller, secluded communities, such as in temples, or in public on squares and marketplaces.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ceremonies often strengthen the solidarity within a society and create a sense of belonging and loyalty to the authorities that were organising them. For that reason, they were often employed by monarchs to legitimise their rule, for example through triumphal marches, coronation ceremonies or complicated court rituals.[PARAGRAPH:2]This complicated ceremonial procedure meant that there was only a limited class of people capable of administering rituals. Over time, this led to the emergence of formal priesthood and organised religion.
TEXT.Chinese: 仪式是在特殊场合进行的具有仪式意义的活动。即使在最早的社会，宗教信仰也常常与需要举行仪式的反复发生的事件联系在一起。这些仪式可能发生在较小的、僻静的社区，例如寺庙，或广场和市场上的公共场所。[段：2 ]仪式通常加强社会内部的团结，并对组织他们的权威产生归属感和忠诚感。由于这个原因，他们常常被君主雇用来使他们的统治合法化，例如通过胜利的游行、加冕典礼或复杂的法庭仪式。[第2段]这个复杂的仪式程序意味着只有有限的一类人能够管理仪式。随着时间的推移，这导致出现了正式的祭司和有组织的宗教。

TEXT.English: Certain inequalities have been a feature of most civilizations since the beginning of recorded history, or earlier. Almost without exception, most women were restricted to low-prestige roles as subordinates to men. Many societies identified a ruling elite or 'native' national majority which was free to condemn religious, racial, or other minorities. Large categories of second-class citizens existed in practically all countries, most frequently women, who lacked the political and economic freedoms enjoyed by men.[PARAGRAPH:2]As great increases in wealth, literacy, and access to communications spread through the developed world in the late 19th and early 20th century, this state of affairs was called into question. Women and racial minorities struggled to achieve equal access to economic opportunities and for the right to vote. Ethnic and linguistic groups overpowered and surrounded by foreigners (especially in the Americas and Australia) fought to preserve their right to raise their own children and maintain their language and traditions in the face of intense pressure to dissolve into the mainstream. In recent decades, issues of sexuality and gender identity have sparked much debate and protest between those striving for equality and those that would deny it to them.[PARAGRAPH:2]The battles for these forms of equality, generally known as "civil rights" were one of the defining social forces of the 20th century, and continue into the 21st.
TEXT.Chinese: 自有记录的历史开始以来，或更早以前，某些不平等一直是大多数文明的特征。几乎无一例外，大多数妇女被限制在作为男性下属的低声望角色。许多社会确定了统治精英或“土著”民族的多数，他们可以自由地谴责宗教、种族或其他少数。几乎所有的国家都有大类别的二等公民，其中最常见的是妇女，她们缺乏男性享有的政治和经济自由。〔2〕在第十九年底和二十世纪初，发达国家的财富、识字率和通信量大幅增加，这种情况是这样的。受到质疑。妇女和少数民族努力实现平等获得经济机会和选举权。面对融入主流的巨大压力，被外国人压倒和包围的种族和语言群体（特别是在美洲和澳大利亚）努力维护他们抚养自己孩子的权利，维护自己的语言和传统。近几十年来，性欲和性别认同问题引起了争取平等的人和反对他们的人之间的争论和抗议。[段落：2 ]对于这些平等形式的斗争，一般称为“公民权利”，是二十世纪决定性的社会力量之一，并持续到第二十一。

TEXT.English: Atomic theory is, in simplest form, the idea that all matter is made up of tiny, indivisible particles called "atoms." The first ancient form of this theory comes from the Greek philosopher Democritus. His atomic theory was founded on the Greek ideas of the geometric order of the universe and of the four elements, which led to some strange ideas. For instance, early supporters of the atomic theory suggested that water might flow because it was made up of icosahedral atoms which, being nearly round, tumbled over each other easily; fire was painful because it was made up of tetrahedral atoms which were sharp and thus damaging. Since there was no evidence for this theory at the time, and no obvious reason to prefer it to the alternatives, it was largely ignored for the following two thousand years.[PARAGRAPH:2]The atomic theory re-emerged around 1800, following early chemists' discovery of new types of chemical elements that seemed more fundamental than things like air and fire. The chemist John Dalton proposed again that all matter was made of atoms, which were neither created nor destroyed in chemical reactions, only reshuffled to form different substances. This theory proved fruitful for 19th century chemistry, although many scientists insisted that it was only a theory.[PARAGRAPH:2]Towards the end of the century, advances in the studies of the spectrum of light emitted by different elements, and the discovery of radioactivity, cast doubt on the premise that atoms were indivisible. Perhaps atoms had some kind of internal structure, and were themselves composed of smaller particles with new and intriguing properties of their own. The first of these particles to be discovered was the electron, a tiny and lightweight particle which carries a strong negative charge, and whose motions form the basis for nearly all electrical, magnetic, and chemical interactions.[PARAGRAPH:2]Further investigation into the structure of the atom using ever more precise and complex instruments and mathematical theories opened up broad vistas of scientific discovery. Various models of atomic structure, such as the "plum pudding" model, the Rutherford atom, and the Bohr atom, were considered, modified, or discarded. Scientists gained more understanding of the mechanisms behind atomic structure, and of how atoms could bind together to form molecules.[PARAGRAPH:2]This led to great advances in practical technology in the latter half of the 20th century. Once the atoms that made them up were understood, chemists could tailor-make molecules to suit their needs. Alloys with strange electrical properties could be used to build advanced calculating machines. And the immense forces locked within the atomic nucleus could be released, for good or for evil.
TEXT.Chinese: 原子理论是一种最简单的理论，认为所有的物质都是由称为“原子”的微小的、不可分割的粒子组成的。这一理论的第一种古老形式来自希腊哲学家德谟克利特。他的原子理论是建立在希腊的宇宙几何秩序和四元素的基础上的，这导致了一些奇怪的想法。例如，原子理论的早期支持者认为，水之所以流动，是因为它是由二十面体原子组成的，而二十面体原子几乎是圆形的，很容易相互碰撞；火之所以令人痛苦，是因为它是由四面体原子组成的，四面体原子锋利，因而具有破坏性。因为当时没有任何证据证明这一理论，也没有明显的理由把它比作替代品，所以在接下来的二千年里，它被忽略了。[段落：2 ]原子理论重新出现在1800左右，在早期化学家发现了比空气和火更基本的新型化学元素之后。化学家约翰道尔顿再次提出，所有的物质都是由原子构成的，原子在化学反应中既没有被创造也没有被破坏，只是经过重组形成不同的物质。这一理论在十九世纪的化学上证明是卓有成效的，尽管许多科学家坚持认为这只是一个理论。[段落：2 ]到本世纪末，对不同元素发射的光谱的研究和放射性的发现的进展，对原子不可分割的前提产生了怀疑。也许原子有某种内部结构，它们本身是由更小的粒子组成的，这些粒子本身有着新奇有趣的特性。这些被发现的粒子中的第一个是电子，一个微小而轻质的粒子，携带着一个强的负电荷，它的运动形成了几乎所有的电、磁和化学相互作用的基础。[段落：2 ]使用更精密和复杂的仪器进一步研究原子的结构。数学理论开辟了科学发现的广阔前景。原子结构的各种模型，如“李子布丁”模型、卢瑟福原子和玻尔原子，都被考虑、修改或废弃。科学家们对原子结构背后的机制有了更多的了解，以及原子是如何结合在一起形成分子的。[段落：2 ]这导致了在二十世纪后半期实用技术的巨大进步。一旦组成它们的原子被理解，化学家就可以根据它们的需要定制分子。具有奇异电性能的合金可以用来制造先进的计算机器。锁在原子核内的巨大力量可以被释放，不管是好是坏。

TEXT.English: Infrastructure is the collective term for all those facilities and systems by which it is possible for human civilizations to carry out productive enterprises and maintain a functional economy. Examples of infrastructure assets include but are not limited to transportation facilities, electrical power grids, financial systems, water supplies, waste disposal facilities, flood control facilities, lighthouses, telecommunication networks, and arguably systems designed to provide services directly to the public such as education systems, law enforcement, public housing, and state-funded hospitals.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some types of infrastructure are nearly always created, maintained, and administered by government agencies. Others lend themselves better to privatization. The question of whether infrastructure should be publicly or privately owned is often hotly debated.[PARAGRAPH:2]The increasingly elaborate nature of infrastructure in advanced, developed societies is one of the main reasons they represent such a vast change in terms of lifestyle and quality of life from pre-industrial times. Industrial-scale projects make it possible to provide basic necessities of life to all citizens with little difficulty, enabling people to concentrate on things other than providing for their sustenance. For instance, a public water system that pipes drinkable water into every home saves a great deal of time and energy compared to requiring every individual to operate their own well, or draw water from a nearby river or lake. It is also possible to make such a water system much healthier and safer than individuals could do alone, and to provide quantities of water that would be an immense laborious undertaking in the absence of the general system of waterworks.[PARAGRAPH:2]While infrastructure makes us safe and prosperous, however, it can also make us vulnerable. Managing infrastructure with safety and reliability can require complex bureaucracy and confining regulations. And in times of war or natural disaster, large parts of a society's infrastructure may be destroyed, forcing thousands or millions of people to do without essential things which they had never lacked before.
TEXT.Chinese: 基础设施是所有这些设施和系统的总称，通过这些设施和系统，人类文明可以开展生产性企业并维持一种功能性经济。基础设施资产的例子包括但不限于交通设施、电网、金融系统、供水、废物处理设施、防洪设施、灯塔、电信网络，以及可论证的旨在直接向公众提供服务的系统，如教育系统、法律实施、公共住房和国家资助的医院。[段落：2 ]某些类型的基础设施几乎总是由政府机构创建、维护和管理。其他人则更倾向于私有化。基础设施应该是公开还是私有的问题经常引起激烈争论。[段落：2 ]发达发达国家的基础设施日益完善，这是它们代表着工业时代生活方式和生活质量的巨大变化的主要原因之一。工业规模的项目使人们能够毫不费力地向所有公民提供基本生活必需品，使人们能够集中精力解决除维持生计以外的其他问题。例如，公共供水系统将饮用水输送到每家每户，与要求每个人自己打井或从附近的河流或湖泊取水相比，节省了大量的时间和精力。也有可能使这样的水系统比个人所能做到的更健康和更安全，并且在没有水务系统的情况下提供大量的水，这将是一项艰巨的任务。[第2段]，虽然基础设施使我们安全和繁荣，但是它也能使我们变得脆弱。以安全和可靠的方式管理基础设施可能需要复杂的官僚机构和限制性法规。在战争或自然灾害时期，一个社会的大部分基础设施可能会被摧毁，迫使成千上万或数百万人在没有以前从未缺少过的必需品的情况下生活。

TEXT.English: While the earliest powered flying machines proved useless for war except as aerial scout platforms, the demands of World War One accelerated development of fast, powerful aircraft capable of hauling significant weapons or cargo. Steady improvements in the internal combustion engine, and rapid growth of experience in airplane design, led to a boom in the airplane's capabilities in the 1920s and 1930s. Passenger aviation in planes like the Douglas DC-3 (still in service today) turned aircraft construction into a major industry. At the same time, military airplanes became more powerful and capable, diversifying into fast, agile fighters and bombers capable of carrying tons of explosives hundreds of kilometres into enemy territory.
TEXT.Chinese: 尽管最早的动力飞行机器被证明除了作为空中侦察平台之外对战争毫无用处，但第一次世界大战的要求加速了能够运载重要武器或货物的快速、强大飞机的发展。内燃机的不断改进和飞机设计经验的迅速增长，导致了20世纪20年代和30年代飞机性能的激增。像道格拉斯DC-3（目前仍在服役）这样的飞机上的乘客航空使飞机制造成为一个主要产业。与此同时，军用飞机变得更加强大和有能力，多样化为快速、灵活的战斗机和轰炸机，能够将数吨炸药运到数百公里外的敌方领土。

TEXT.English: Pastoralism is a term for the art of raising livestock. It is also used in sociology, to describe a way of life that revolves around herding and caring for domestic animals. Pastoral societies are generally most successful on poorly productive land such as large, dry stretches of desert, savannah, hills, or tundra. In this sort of terrain, dense stands of food crops cannot be grown naturally, so farming is impossible without modern irrigation. However, in such biomes there is a substantial natural supply of grasses and shrubs; humans cannot eat them, but sheep, cattle, goats, or yaks can.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is often but not always the case that a pastoral people 'follows their herds,' moving from one part of the land they occupy to another to ensure that they have access to the best available grazing, water supplies, and a healthy climate for their animals.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pastoral societies present a common alternative to agricultural societies, and were capable of functioning and thriving on equal terms with them up until the rise of modern technology. They could be particularly effective in warfare, especially when leaders took advantage of their self-sufficient, highly mobile lifestyle to create an army of self-sufficient, highly mobile soldiers. In modern times, however, the inability of small pastoral communities to manufacture modern weapons, coupled with overpopulation problems, have made it less sustainable and practical for these peoples to live in their traditional mode.
TEXT.Chinese: 畜牧业是畜牧业的一个术语。它也被用于社会学，用来描述一种围绕放牧和照顾家畜的生活方式。牧民社会通常最成功的是在生产力低下的土地上，如沙漠、草原、丘陵或苔原的大片干旱地带。在这种地形下，密集的粮食作物不能自然生长，因此没有现代灌溉，农业是不可能的。然而，在这样的生物群落中，草和灌木的自然供应量很大；人类不能食用它们，但绵羊、牛、山羊或牦牛也可以食用。[段落：2 ]牧羊人跟随牧群的情况常常是这样，但并非总是如此。他们从土地的一部分迁移到另一块土地，以确保他们能够获得最好的放牧、供水和动物的健康气候。〔2〕牧场社会是农业社会的共同选择，直到现代科技的兴起，他们才能够在平等的条件下运作和繁荣。它们在战争中可能特别有效，特别是当领导人利用其自给自足、高度机动的生活方式创建一支自给自足、高度机动的士兵大军时。然而，在现代，小牧区无法制造现代武器，再加上人口过剩的问题，使这些民族以传统方式生活的可持续性和实用性降低。

TEXT.English: Ecology is the science of studying biological systems in nature, as distinct from the processes that go on inside individual organisms or species. Ecologists focus on understanding how different species interact in their natural habitats, what causes some to flourish and others to fade, what patterns persist across all examples of a given biome (such as 'forest' or 'savannah'), and what difference may make one area unique compared to others that are superficially similar. Knowledge of ecology helps to predict the future of a living system, control outbreaks of diseases such as blights in the wild, and mitigate certain types of natural disaster such as floods and wildfires.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ecological discoveries over the late 19th and 20th centuries have made humanity far more aware of the complexities of life on Earth, and how human actions impact these complexities.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]人类几千年来享受着自然的恩惠却不以为意。当文明不断成长，人类遍布了这个星球表面每一个角落，他们不顾自然界的承受力，拿去他们想要的，扔出更多他们不需要的垃圾。在20世纪60年代后期，越来越多的人开始关注污染以及破坏自然环境所引起的越来越多的问题。这个运动导致了如美国环保局等团体的形成。[PARAGRAPH:2]美国环保局的目标是减少各种各样的污染。为了这个目的，该局订制了一系列严格的法律和方针，涉及到有害物质的处理、清洁水的标准以及鼓励固体废弃物处理技术的研究等。环境运动的基本目标是使环境保持安全完好，能够让子孙后代享受。

TEXT.English: By late 20th century, physics had converged on a set of well understood theories to describe nature. But there are several gaps, defects, or vulnerabilities in this universal model. Firstly, this set of theories stands on two pillars. One is the nature of gravity, as outlined by Einstein's theory of "general relativity" in 1920 and refined since that time, which treats time and space as flexible things that can be warped by gravity. The other is "quantum field theory," which describes the behavior of subatomic particles, treating each particle as a special instance of a generalized, abstract field of force and probability that permeates the universe.[PARAGRAPH:2]The problem is that quantum field theory, otherwise known as the Standard Model, assumes that time and space are fixed, inflexible, and invariant - that they are the constant and unchanging playing field on which particle interactions are allowed to happen. In other words, the Standard Model does not obey the theory of relativity. Therefore, it cannot be the whole story. General relativity appears to be a solid and essentially complete picture of a key part of reality, the Standard Model is not. It is solid, it explains the behavior of nearly all things that can be seen on Earth or elsewhere in the universe... but it is not complete.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Standard Model explains almost all known phenomena, but some of the ones it cannot explain present very large issues. It does not explain the nature or origins of dark matter or dark energy and yet astronomers have reason to believe that these things make up 95% of all substance in the universe today. The Standard Model does not explain why the ghostly neutrino particles coming from the Sun appear to randomly reshuffle their nature, in a way the Standard Model deems impossible. The Standard Model predicts that in the beginning of the universe, matter and antimatter 'should' have been created in equal quantities, and devoured each other totally, leaving behind nothing but light and radiation in all of space. In hindsight, this appears not to have occurred. For this and other reasons, despite the Standard Model providing huge advances in our understanding compared to anything that came before it, it is not the last step.[PARAGRAPH:2]Research into these matters is ongoing today. It is hoped that future physics will emerge which resolves some of these contradictions. In particular, it is hoped that these new physics will allow us to create a model of quantum physics that is consistent with Einstein's work on gravity - thus the name, "quantum gravity."
TEXT.Chinese: 到了20世纪末，物理学已经融合到一套很好理解的描述自然的理论上。但是，在这个通用模型中有几个漏洞、缺陷或漏洞。首先，这套理论有两个支柱。一个是引力的本质，1920年爱因斯坦的“广义相对论”概述了这一点，并从那时起加以完善，认为时间和空间是可以被引力扭曲的灵活事物。另一种是“量子场论”，它描述了亚原子粒子的行为，把每个粒子看作是一个广义、抽象的力场和渗透宇宙的概率的特殊实例。〔2〕问题是量子场论，否则称为标准模型，假设时间和空间是固定的、不可改变的和不变的，它们是允许粒子相互作用发生的恒定不变的运动场。换句话说，标准模型并不遵循相对论。因此，它不可能是整个故事。广义相对论似乎是一个坚实而基本完整的现实图景的关键部分，标准模型则不然。它是固体的，它解释了几乎所有可以在地球上或宇宙其他地方看到的事物的行为。。。但是它不是完全的。[段落：2 ]标准模型解释了几乎所有已知的现象，但是一些不能解释的现象呈现出非常大的问题。它并不能解释暗物质或暗能量的性质或起源，然而天文学家有理由相信这些物质占了当今宇宙所有物质的95%。标准模型并不能解释为什么来自太阳的幽灵般的中微子粒子会以标准模型认为不可能的方式随机改变它们的性质。标准模型预测，在宇宙诞生之初，物质和反物质“应该”以相等的数量被创造出来，并相互完全吞噬，在整个空间中只留下光和辐射。事后看来，这似乎并没有发生。由于这个和其他的原因，尽管标准模型在我们的理解中提供了巨大的进步，与之前的任何事情相比，它并不是最后的步骤。[段落：2 ]对这些问题的研究正在进行中。人们希望未来的物理学能够出现，从而解决其中的一些矛盾。特别是，人们希望这些新的物理学能让我们创造出一个量子物理学模型，这个模型与爱因斯坦关于引力的工作是一致的，因此被称为“量子引力”

TEXT.English: Leather is a hard-wearing, flexible material created by curing and drying animal skins. Forms of leather can be made using Stone Age technology (curing hides with materials like lime or animal brains), or more complex chemical processes. Leather has been in use since at least the second millenium BC, as proven by finds of leather samples over 3000 years old in archaeological digs. Since leather does not last forever under normal conditions, its invention very probably came earlier.[PARAGRAPH:2]Leather can be made from the skin of almost any large animal, with a variety of qualities. Depending on how it is tanned, it can be flexible or stiff, soft or rough. It is generally waterproof, fairly effective at keeping in heat, and resistant to rotting or decay. Properly oiled and maintained, it can survive desert sandstorms or frozen tundra conditions. It can even be boiled for hardness and used as a form of cheap, lightweight armor protection.[PARAGRAPH:2]Unlike other fabrics such as linen, cotton, and silk, leather can be made even by nomadic cultures. If the nomads kill a domestic or wild animal, and have a suitable tanning process. On the other hand, leather remains useful in farming societies, especially those with large herd animals such as cattle.[PARAGRAPH:2]Because it is sturdy and cannot be unraveled like normal cloth, leather can be decorated with a variety of hole-punches, stitches, and decorative studs. Decorative leather goods are a popular form of arts and crafts in many societies. Today, advances in synthetic plastics have made leather less important, and it has now become more of a fashion statement and luxury good than a major fabric in practical use.
TEXT.Chinese: 皮革是一种由动物皮肤固化和干燥而成的耐磨、柔软的材料。皮革的形式可以使用石器时代的技术（用石灰或动物脑等材料来固化皮革）或更复杂的化学过程。皮革至少在公元前两千年就开始使用了，在考古发掘中发现的3000多年前的皮革样品证明了这一点。由于皮革在正常情况下不会持续下去，所以它的发明很可能来得更早。[段落：2 ]皮革可以由几乎任何大型动物的皮肤制成，具有多种特性。取决于它是如何被晒黑的，它可以是柔韧的或坚硬的，柔软的或粗糙的。它通常是防水的，在保持热量方面相当有效，并且抗腐烂或腐烂。经过适当的润滑和维护，它可以在沙漠沙尘暴或冻土条件下生存。它甚至可以煮成硬度，用作廉价、轻质装甲防护。[段落：2 ]不同于其他织物，例如亚麻、棉花和丝绸，皮革甚至可以由游牧文化制成。如果游牧民族杀死家畜或野生动物，并有一个合适的晒黑过程。另一方面，皮革在农业社会中仍然有用，尤其是那些有大量牲畜的动物，如牛。[段落：2 ]，因为它是坚固的，不能像普通布一样被解开，皮革可以用各种打孔、缝线和装饰钉装饰。装饰性皮革制品是许多社会中流行的一种工艺品。如今，合成塑料的进步使得皮革不再那么重要，它现在更像是一种时尚宣言和奢侈品，而不是一种实用的主要面料。

TEXT.English: Healthcare is the practice of acting so as to preserve or restore the health of the individual patient, although this is normally construed to not include basic sustenance needs such as air, water, and food. Healthcare can be divided into a wide range of overlapping categories. These include but are not limited to preventative care (to maintain health through nutrition, exercise, and hygiene), palliative care (to relieve the symptoms of a patient who cannot be cured by the available means), outpatient care (where the patient is able to function and live independently while undergoing treatment), urgent care (treatment of pressing medical problems that are nonetheless not life-threatening), and acute care (where a patient requires detailed monitoring or complex medical support and so must remain in a hospital with physicians in attendance).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Since it affects what may be the foremost concern of nearly all humans - their health - health care occupies a large share of the total time and energy of the human race. Many (though not all) of the professionals involved in providing health care receive unusual prestige and wealth within their own societies. This was the case even in ancient times when the practice of medicine was primitive to the point of being life-threatening.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In modern times, the health care system has become an elaborate and refined infrastructure, especially in developed nations. Not only is it an industry in its own right, it supports various other industries such as the pharmaceutical industry and the insurance industry. The challenge of working out how to efficiently pay for this vast system that keeps us alive and relatively comfortable is a subject of energetic debate in many societies.
TEXT.Chinese: 医疗保健是指为了保护或恢复患者个体的健康而采取的行动，尽管这通常被解释为不包括诸如空气、水和食物等基本的营养需要。医疗保健可以分为许多重叠的类别。这些包括但不限于预防性护理（通过营养、锻炼和卫生来保持健康）、姑息性护理（缓解无法通过可用手段治愈的患者的症状）、门诊护理（患者在接受治疗时能够独立工作和生活）、紧急护理（治疗紧迫的医疗问题，但并不危及生命）和急性护理（患者需要详细的监测或复杂的医疗支持，因此必须留在医院，有医生在场）。[新线][新线]因为它影响到几乎所有人类最关心的问题-他们的健康保健占人类总时间和精力的很大一部分。许多（尽管不是全部）参与提供医疗保健的专业人员在他们自己的社会中获得了不寻常的声望和财富。即使在古代，医学的实践还很原始，到了危及生命的地步，这种情况仍然存在。在现代，医疗保健系统已经成为一个精心设计和完善的基础设施，特别是在发达国家。它不仅本身是一个行业，它还支持其他各种行业，如制药业和保险业。在许多社会中，如何有效地为这个让我们保持活力和相对舒适的庞大体系买单，是一个充满活力的争论话题。

TEXT.English: The term "composite" refers to any object that is made up of more than one material. Composites were used quite early in human history; composite bows have been discovered dating back to 1300 BC. The composite technology refers the late 20th Century invention of various metal and plastic composites with greater strength, lightness, and other special properties than the base materials.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kevlar, the modern battle armor, is a composite material. Modern tanks are constructed of steel-boron nitride composites. Stealth airplanes use composite materials that are much more difficult to spot on radar. The tungsten-carbide composite is used in drill bits and wedding rings. Composite materials often demand extremely complex and precise manufacturing processes. However expensive the process may be, the resulting material may have superior qualities that make them more than worth the expense.
TEXT.Chinese: “复合材料”一词是指由一种以上材料构成的任何物体。复合材料在人类历史上很早就被使用；复合弓的发现可以追溯到公元前1300年。复合材料技术是指二十世纪底发明的各种金属和塑料复合材料，具有比基体材料更大的强度、轻质和其他特殊性能。〔2〕凯夫拉，现代战斗装甲，是一种复合材料。现代坦克是由钢氮化硼复合材料。隐形飞机使用的复合材料在雷达上很难被发现。碳化钨复合材料用于钻头和结婚戒指。复合材料往往需要极其复杂和精确的制造工艺。无论工艺多么昂贵，所得到的材料可能具有优越的质量，使它们比所花的费用更值钱。

TEXT.English: Civil liberties are forms of freedom of action which the state is required to give to all citizens, without limits or with very minimal limits.[PARAGRAPH:2]The idea that one's standing in society confers certain rights is ancien t- most traditional societies grant special immunities to nobles and priests, granting them more room to speak their minds and more confidence of avoiding practices like torture and arbitrary arrest. But in most of the world, the notion that these rights should be universal is relatively new. Similarly, the belief that they should apply without exception even when the state has an interest in ignoring them, as a matter of principle date back to no earlier than the Enlightenment of the 1600s and 1700s.[PARAGRAPH:2]Key among these basic rights are freedom of speech, freedom of religion, the right to vote, and freedom from arbitrary use of police powers. Removing any of these rights makes it far easier for a tyrannical government to suppress dissent, while keeping them in place helps to ensure that the state remains honest, forthright, and responsible in its dealings with the citizenry.
TEXT.Chinese: 公民自由是国家需要给予公民的行动自由的形式，无限制或极少的限制。[段落：2 ]社会地位赋予某些权利的观念是古老的――大多数传统社会赋予贵族和牧师特殊豁免权，让他们有更多的空间表达自己的想法，更有信心避免酷刑和任意逮捕等做法。但在世界大多数地区，这些权利应该是普遍的这一概念是相对较新的。同样，即使在国家有兴趣忽视他们的情况下，他们也应该毫无例外地适用，原则上追溯到1600年和1700年的启蒙运动。[段落：2 ]这些基本权利中的关键是言论自由、宗教自由、选举权。以及不任意使用警察权力的自由。剥夺这些权利使专制政府更容易压制异见，而保留这些权利有助于确保国家在与公民打交道时保持诚实、直率和负责任。

TEXT.English: Geography is a field of science devoted to the study of the lands, the features, the inhabitants, and the phenomena of Earth. The first person to use the word geography was Eratosthenes (276-194 BC). Geography is an all-encompassing discipline that seeks an understanding of the Earth and its human and natural complexities - not merely where objects are, but how they have changed and come to be. It is often defined in terms of the two branches of human geography and physical geography.[PARAGRAPH:2]The European Age of Discovery during the 16th and the 17th centuries, where many new lands were discovered and accounts by European explorers such as Christopher Columbus, Marco Polo, and James Cook revived a desire for both accurate geographic detail, and more solid theoretical foundations in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]The 18th and the 19th centuries were the times when geography became recognized as a discrete academic discipline, and became part of a typical university curriculum in Europe (especially Paris and Berlin).
TEXT.Chinese: 地理学是一门专门研究土地、地貌、居民和地球现象的科学。第一个使用地理这个词的人是埃拉托舍内斯（公元前276-194年）。地理学是一门包罗万象的学科，它寻求对地球及其人类和自然复杂性的理解――不仅仅是物体在哪里，而是它们是如何变化和形成的。它经常被定义为人类地理和自然地理的两个分支。[段落：2 ]在第十六和第十七世纪发现的欧洲时代，许多新的土地被发现，并由欧洲探险家Christopher Columbus、马可波罗和詹姆斯・库克所做的记述恢复了对精确地理的渴望。细节，更坚实的理论基础在欧洲。[段落：2 ]第十八和第十九个世纪是地理被认为是一个离散的学科，并成为一个典型的大学课程在欧洲（尤其是巴黎和柏林）的一部分。

TEXT.English: An explosive is a chemical compound or mixture that undergoes rapid combustion and produces heat, gas, and pressure effects. The earliest explosive compound known was gunpowder, which was first used in the13th century, and was the only explosive known for hundreds of years. The first modern explosive, a compound known as nitroglycerin, was discovered in 1846. Compounds similar to nitroglycerin are the most commonly used explosives today. Explosives vary in brisance, or shattering effect, and in their stability under various environmental conditions. Aside from their obvious use in weaponry, explosives are also used in such peaceful applications as rocket propellants and for mining and demolition work.
TEXT.Chinese: 炸药是一种化合物或混合物，经过快速燃烧，产生热量、气体和压力效应。已知最早的爆炸物是火药，最早使用于13世纪，是数百年来唯一已知的爆炸物。第一种现代炸药，一种叫做硝化甘油的化合物，于1846年被发现。类似硝化甘油的化合物是当今最常用的炸药。炸药在不同的环境条件下，其威力或破碎效果以及稳定性各不相同。爆炸物除了明显用于武器之外，还用于火箭推进剂等和平用途以及采矿和爆破工作。

TEXT.English: A contract is a voluntary arrangement between two or more parties that is enforceable by law as a binding legal agreement. A contract arises when the parties agree that there is an agreement. Formation of a contract generally requires an offer, acceptance, consideration, and a mutual intent to be bound. Some types of contracts may require formalities, such as a memorialization in writing.[PARAGRAPH:2]In The Laws, Plato recognized the same basic categories for cancelling agreements as exist today. Roman law identified discrete categories of contractual transaction, each with its own requirements, which needed to be fulfilled in order for promises to be enforced. More than appeared from the general rules in Ancient Greece, Roman law represented an early division between specific kinds of contract, depending on the transaction's nature.
TEXT.Chinese: 合同是两个或多个当事方之间的自愿安排，可作为一项有约束力的法律协议在法律上强制执行。当双方同意有协议时，合同就产生了。合同的订立一般要求要约、承诺、对价和相互的意思表示受约束。某些类型的合同可能需要手续，如书面记述。〔第2款〕在法律中，Plato承认与今天一样取消协议的基本类别。罗马法确定了合同交易的不同类别，每一种都有自己的要求，为了使承诺得到执行，这些要求必须得到履行。罗马法不仅仅出现在古希腊的一般规则中，它还代表着根据交易的性质对特定类型合同的早期划分。

TEXT.English: The humanities are the academic disciplines which study human behavior, organization, society, and culture. They include but are not limited to philosophy, history, archaeology, anthropology, theology, classical studies, law, semiotics, linguistics, and the arts. The fields collectively known as the humanities are generally pursued by specialized scholars or artists, who work steadily to refine their aesthetic sense, their understanding of the human condition, and their knowledge of the proper order of human affairs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While it is generally difficult to point to specific physical benefits garnered from these fields, collectively they make up almost all that motivates the human race. Without art, law, religion, history, and philosophy, human civilizations are at a loss as to how to organize themselves or what goals they should orient themselves towards.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Individuals may pursue self-gratification or bare survival in the absence of these things, but social cohesion tends to break down rapidly when this is all that people have and share with each other. Thus, the humanities form the mortar, the glue, the nuts and bolts, that hold civilizations together.
TEXT.Chinese: 人文学科是研究人类行为、组织、社会和文化的学科。它们包括但不限于哲学、历史、考古学、人类学、神学、古典研究、法律、符号学、语言学和艺术。这些统称为人文学科的领域通常是由专门的学者或艺术家所追求的，他们不断地努力完善自己的美感、对人类状况的理解，以及他们对人类事务的正确顺序的知识。[新线][新线]虽然通常很难指出从这些领域获得的具体物质利益，但他们共同构成了几乎所有激励人类的因素。没有艺术、法律、宗教、历史和哲学，人类文明就无法组织自己，也无法确定自己的目标，但是，当人们拥有并分享这些东西时，社会凝聚力往往会迅速瓦解。因此，人文学科形成了灰泥、胶水、螺母和螺栓，它们把文明团结在一起。

TEXT.English: One of the most important steps in the move toward industrialization was the ability to precisely shape or 'machine' solid metal into a desired form. Through mechanical, chemical, and other means, machine tools mold and shape raw materials into precision parts for complex machinery. The first machine tool, a horizontal boring device, was produced in the late 1700s.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The development of measuring devices accurate to within thousandths of an inch allowed for the mass production of items with interchangeable parts. The technology of the 20th century has produced computer-controlled machine tools that can be adapted to a wide variety of applications. The speed and accuracy of these machines allows for the economical mass production of extremely complex products.
TEXT.Chinese: 工业化进程中最重要的一步是能够精确地将固态金属成形或“加工”成所需的形状。通过机械、化工等手段，将机床模具和成型原材料加工成精密零件，用于复杂机械。第一台机床，一种水平钻孔装置，是在17世纪后期生产的。[新线][新线]测量装置的发展精确到千分之一英寸，允许批量生产具有可互换零件的产品。20世纪的技术已经产生了计算机控制的机床，可以适应各种各样的应用。这些机器的速度和精度允许经济批量生产极其复杂的产品。

TEXT.English: Horticulture is the art of cultivating plants for human use. By the late Middle Ages, the techniques of growing plants by hand and muscle power had been under refinement for millenia. Staple crops like wheat, rice, and potatoes were about as refined and optimized as possible. Immense bodies of farming lore arose, about the best practices for growing plants in a given land, under varying conditions of soil conditions, temperature, day length, rainfall, parasites, disease and predation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The careful and professional science of crop-growing played a large role in the pre-industrial Age of Colonialism. Knowing how best to produce staple crops also made it easier to mass-cultivate luxury crops for export. Since most luxury crops grew best in certain climates and soils under the eyes of local populations who knew how to cultivate them (tobacco in the New World, tea in the Far East), this opened up new routes for trade and investment around the world.
TEXT.Chinese: 园艺是为人类种植植物的艺术。到了中世纪晚期，用手和肌肉力量种植植物的技术已经在千禧年得到改进。小麦、水稻和土豆等主要作物都经过了尽可能精炼和优化。在不同的土壤条件、温度、日长、降雨量、寄生虫、疾病和捕食条件下，关于在特定土地上种植植物的最佳做法的大量农业知识应运而生。知道如何最好地生产主食作物也使大量种植高档作物出口变得更加容易。由于大多数豪华作物在某些气候和土壤中生长得最好，而当地居民知道如何种植（新世界的烟草、远东的茶叶），这为世界各地的贸易和投资开辟了新的途径。

TEXT.English: "All is interrelated. Heaven and earth, air and water. All are but one thing; not four, not two and not three, but one. Where they are not together, there is only an incomplete piece."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Paracelsus
TEXT.Chinese: “一切都是相互关联的。天地，空气和水。一切都是一回事，不是四，不是二，不是三，而是一。他们不在一起的地方，只有一个不完整的部分。”[段落：2 ] - Paracelsus

TEXT.English: As agricultural productivity increased and the demand for specialist goods increased, it became less practical and less desirable to keep control of these industries in the hands of rulers. The invention of currency-based trade made independent life as a merchant or professional easier, especially in urban and semi-urbanized areas. Such trade also contributed to the rising influence of the proto-middle class, and promoted long-range commerce. The availability of rare goods at trading hubs increased, and centers of production where specialist goods were made profited.
TEXT.Chinese: 随着农业生产力的提高和对专业产品需求的增加，将这些行业的控制权掌握在统治者手中变得不那么实际和不那么可取。货币贸易的发明使商人或职业人士的独立生活变得更容易，特别是在城市和半城市化地区。这种贸易也促进了原始中产阶级影响力的上升，促进了长期贸易。贸易中心稀有商品的供应量增加，专门生产商品的生产中心获利。

TEXT.English: Journalism is the profession of investigating and reporting on news of interest to the journalist's readers, listeners, or viewers. Journalism plays an important role in economics and politics, by allowing the masses to access information that would otherwise be available only to a lucky, connected few.[PARAGRAPH:2]Journalism as we now know it comes from the rise of news corporations (particularly newspapers, in the 19th and 20th centuries), improved transportation and communications that allowed correspondents to move about, learn things, and report back to headquarters quickly, and the rise of mass literacy among the general public in the 18th and 19th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the middle and late 20th century the rise of radio and television created new media for journalists to distribute information. At the same time they changed the dynamics of how news flowed through the system, and what sorts of information could be presented, culminating in concepts like the "sound bite" and the "24-hour news cycle." Today, journalism is undergoing a sea change, as the old newspapers struggle to maintain public readership in the age of the internet, while critics argue that the television news have become bland tools for soothing and manipulating the masses instead of informing them. At the same time, vast numbers of enterprising individuals have taken it upon themselves to document and comment on the news online, creating a sphere of private, individualized online journalism.[PARAGRAPH:2]The relationship between the "fourth estate" of journalists and government power is always uneasy. In dictatorships, state control of the media blurs the line between journalism and propaganda. Even in democratic nations, the organized media may be afraid of losing access to the corridors of power, of political concerns, or of undermining their own positions as wealthy information-handling organizations.
TEXT.Chinese: 新闻业是调查和报道记者的读者、听众或观众感兴趣的新闻的职业。新闻学在经济和政治中起着重要的作用，它允许大众访问那些只对幸运的、有联系的少数人有用的信息。[第2段]新闻，我们现在知道它来自于新闻公司的崛起（尤其是在第十九和第二十世纪的报纸）。改善了交通和通讯，使通讯员能够快速移动、学习和向总部汇报，第十八和第十九世纪普通大众的大众文化的兴起。[段落：2 ]在二十世纪中后期，广播和电视的兴起为新闻工作者创造了新的传播信息的媒介。与此同时，他们改变了新闻在系统中流动的动态，以及可以呈现的信息种类，最终形成了“声音咬合”和“24小时新闻周期”等概念。今天，新闻业正经历着翻天覆地的变化，因为旧报纸在互联网时代难以保持公众读者，而批评人士认为，电视新闻已经成为安抚和操纵大众的平淡工具，而不是告知大众。与此同时，大量的有进取心的个人也开始自己对网络新闻进行评论和评论，创造出一个私人的、个性化的网络新闻领域。[第2段]记者和政府权力的“第四产业”之间的关系一直是不稳定的。在独裁统治下，国家对媒体的控制模糊了新闻和宣传之间的界限。即使在民主国家，有组织的媒体也可能害怕失去进入权力走廊的机会，害怕失去政治关切，害怕破坏自己作为富有的信息处理组织的地位。

TEXT.English: "There hammer on the anvil smote, there chisel clove and graver wrote; There forged was blade and bound was hilt; The delver mined, the mason built."[PARAGRAPH:2]- J. R. R. Tolkien, The Lord of the Rings
TEXT.Chinese: “铁锤上有锤子，凿子和雕刻刀写在那里；锻造的是刀刃，被缚的是刀柄；德弗尔铸造的是石匠建造的。”[段：2 ] -J.R.R.托尔金，指环王。

TEXT.English: Fertilizers are substances which increase the fertility of soil by introducing nutrients that are often lacking. Since deficiencies in substances like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium are often bottlenecks in plant growth, fertilizer makes plants to grow larger and more quickly. This is especially desirable in agriculture as it allows the same land to feed more people.[PARAGRAPH:2]Fertilization has been a common practice throughout the civilized world since prehistoric times. Farmers in nearly all places fertilized their fields with simple materials like animal (or human) dung, ground-up fish remains, or potsherds (most fertile soil in the Amazon basin is laced with broken pottery, and this appears to have been deliberate on the natives' part).[PARAGRAPH:2]During the 19th and 20th centuries, the range of available fertilizers grew dramatically. Industrial-scale extraction of minerals, particularly nitrates and phosphates, allowed vast increases in farm output. Advances in industrial chemistry allowed factories to create fully synthetic fertilizers too, using customized organic molecules to speed the growth of crops and inhibit the growth of weeds and parasites. This contributes to the success of the "Green Revolution" of the 1960s and 1970s at feeding a world population of seven billion and rising.[PARAGRAPH:2]In general, fertilizer achieves varying success. Used carelessly, it may not contribute to soil fertility (adding more of what's already there is pointless), or even decrease it (adding enough phosphorus to maximize growth may result in all the carbon in the soil being used up quickly). This is a particularly serious problem with "Green Revolution" crops in the modern era. Furthermore, careless or excessive use can lead to fertilizer seeping into waterways, causing oxygen depletion, algal blooms, and other ecological problems.
TEXT.Chinese: 肥料是通过引入经常缺乏的养分来提高土壤肥力的物质。由于氮、磷、钾等物质的缺乏往往是植物生长的瓶颈，肥料使植物生长得更大更快。在农业上，这是特别可取的，因为它允许同一土地养活更多的人。[段落：2 ]自史前时代以来，施肥一直是文明世界中的一种普遍做法。几乎所有地方的农民用动物（或人）粪便、地上的鱼遗骸或陶器（Amazon盆地中最肥沃的土壤都是破损的陶器）来种植田地，这在第十九和第二十个世纪中是故意的。可用肥料的范围急剧扩大。工业规模的矿物开采，特别是硝酸盐和磷酸盐的开采，使农业产量大幅增加。工业化学的进步也使工厂能够制造出完全合成的肥料，使用定制的有机分子来加速作物的生长，抑制杂草和寄生虫的生长。这有助于在20世纪60年代和70年代的“绿色革命”中成功地养活世界人口七十亿和上升。[段落：2 ]一般来说，肥料获得了不同的成功。如果不小心使用，它可能不会增加土壤肥力（增加更多已经没有意义的东西），甚至会降低肥力（增加足够的磷以使生长最大化，可能会导致土壤中的所有碳迅速消耗殆尽）。这是当代“绿色革命”作物面临的一个特别严重的问题。此外，不小心或过度使用会导致肥料渗入河道，导致氧气耗尽、藻类大量繁殖和其他生态问题。

TEXT.English: "The cause of nutrition and growth resides not in the organism as a whole but in the separate elementary parts - the cells."[PARAGRAPH:2]- Theodor Schwann, Microscopical Researches into the Accordance in the Structure and Growth of Animals and Plants

TEXT.English: Power projection (or force projection) is a term used in military and political science to refer to the capacity of a state to apply all or some of its elements of national power - political, economic, informational, or military - to rapidly and effectively deploy and sustain forces in and from multiple dispersed locations to respond to crises, to contribute to deterrence, and to enhance regional stability.[PARAGRAPH:2]This ability is a crucial element of a state's power in international relations. Any state able to direct its military forces outside the limited bounds of its territory might be said to have some level of power projection capability, but the term itself is used most frequently in reference to militaries with a worldwide reach (or at least significantly broader than a state's immediate area). Even states with sizable hard power assets (such as a large standing army) may only be able to exert limited regional influence so long as they lack the means of effectively projecting their power on a global scale. Generally, only a select few states are able to overcome the logistical difficulties inherent in the deployment and direction of a modern, mechanized military force.[PARAGRAPH:2]The aircraft carrier strike group, strategic bomber, ballistic missile submarine, and strategic airlifter are all examples of power projection platforms. Military units designed to be light and mobile, such as airborne forces (paratroopers and air assault forces) and amphibious assault forces, are utilized in power projection. Forward basing is another method of power projection, which, by pre-positioning military units or stockpiles of arms at strategically located military bases outside a country's territory, reduces the time and distance needed to mobilize them.
TEXT.Chinese: 权力投射（或武力投射）是军事和政治科学中的一个术语，指一个国家运用其全部或部分国家权力要素（政治、经济、信息或军事）在多个分散地点迅速有效地部署和维持部队以应对危机的能力有助于威慑，增强地区稳定。[第2段]这种能力是国家在国际关系中的力量的关键因素。任何能够将其军事力量引向其领土范围以外的国家都可以说具有某种程度的力量投射能力，但这一术语本身最常用于指在全世界范围内（或至少比一个国家的直接地区大得多）的军事。即使是拥有大量硬实力资产的国家（如一支庞大的常备军），只要它们缺乏在全球范围有效投射其实力的手段，也可能只能发挥有限的区域影响力。一般来说，只有少数几个州能够克服现代机械化军事力量的部署和方向所固有的后勤困难。[第2段]航母打击群、战略轰炸机、弹道导弹潜艇和战略空中升降机都是动力投射平台的例子。设计为轻型和机动的军事单位，如空降部队（伞兵和空袭部队）和两栖攻击部队，都被用于力量投射。前向基地是另一种力量投射方法，通过在一国领土以外的战略军事基地预先部署军事单位或储存武器，减少动员军事单位所需的时间和距离。

TEXT.English: Transhumanism is an international and intellectual movement that aims to transform the human condition by developing and making widely available sophisticated technologies to greatly enhance human intellect and physiology.[PARAGRAPH:2]Transhumanist thinkers study the potential benefits and dangers of emerging technologies that could overcome fundamental human - as well as ethical - limitations of utilizing such technologies. The most common transhumanist thesis is that human beings may eventually be able to transform themselves into different beings with abilities so greatly expanded from the natural condition as to merit the label of posthuman beings.
TEXT.Chinese: “传播学”是一项国际性和智力性的运动，旨在通过开发和制造广泛可用的尖端技术来改变人类的状况，从而大大提高人类的智力和生理学。〔2〕跨文化思想家研究新兴技术所能克服的潜在益处和危险。利用这类技术的基本人类和伦理限制。最常见的跨人文主义论断是，人类最终可能会将自己转变成不同的人，其能力从自然条件大大扩展，因此值得贴上后人类的标签。

TEXT.English: Tourism is travel for pleasure or business; also the theory and practice of touring, the business of attracting, accommodating, and entertaining tourists, and the business of operating tours. Tourism may be international, or within the traveller's country. The World Tourism Organization defines tourism more generally, in terms which go "beyond the common perception of tourism as being limited to holiday activity only", as people "traveling to and staying in places outside their usual environment for not more than one consecutive year for leisure, business and other purposes".[PARAGRAPH:2]Tourism can be domestic or international, and international tourism has both incoming and outgoing implications on a country's balance of payments. Today, tourism is a major source of income for many countries, and affects the economy of both the source and host countries, in some cases being of vital importance.
TEXT.Chinese: 旅游业是为娱乐或商务目的而进行的旅行；也是旅游业的理论和实践、吸引、容纳和娱乐游客的业务以及经营旅游业的业务。旅游业可以是国际性的，也可以是在旅行者的国家内。世界旅游组织对旅游的定义更为普遍，“旅游”仅限于“仅限于假日活动”，因为人们“旅行和停留在通常环境之外的地方，不超过一年的休闲、商业和其他目的”。无论是国内旅游还是国际旅游，国际旅游都会对一国的国际收支产生影响。今天，旅游业是许多国家的主要收入来源，对来源国和东道国的经济都有影响，在某些情况下至关重要。

TEXT.English: Automation is the art of making machines which perform tasks on their own, without active input or oversight from a human operator. Automatic constructs have existed as toys for the rich since ancient times, the products of individual craftsmanship, but widespread use of automation to control machines is a twentieth-century phenomenon.[PARAGRAPH:2]The demand for automation first came from the need to make machinery function where humans cannot or will not; be it in an extremely hostile environment, in a factory where machines ran faster than the human eye can follow, or in a job too menial and unstimulating for the average person to be content doing. Over time, automation has become more popular and flexible, especially with the rise of electronic computers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Automatic equipment invariably saves human labor, but it also displaces labour. The simple tasks involved in doing the machine's job are replaced by specialized jobs tending the machines. Or not replaced at all.
TEXT.Chinese: 自动化是一门制造机器的艺术，这些机器可以自己执行任务，而不需要人工的积极投入或监督。自古以来，自动构造作为富足玩具已经存在，是个体工艺的产物，但是自动化控制机器的广泛使用是一个二十世纪的现象。[第2段]自动化的需求首先来自于使机器功能在人类不能或不需要的地方；无论是在极端恶劣的环境中，在机器运行速度超过人眼所能跟随的工厂，还是在一个对普通人来说太卑微、太不刺激的工作中。随着时间的推移，自动化已经变得越来越普及和灵活，特别是随着电子计算机的兴起。〔2〕自动化设备总是节省人力，但也代替劳动。做机器工作所涉及的简单任务被照料机器的专门工作所取代。或者根本没有被替换。

TEXT.English: Urban planning is a technical and political process concerned with the development and use of land, planning permission, protection and use of the environment, public welfare, and the design of the urban environment, including air, water, and the infrastructure passing into and out of urban areas, such as transportation, communications, and distribution networks. Urban planning is also referred to as urban and regional planning, regional planning, town planning, city planning, rural planning or some combination in various areas worldwide. It takes many forms and it can share perspectives and practices with urban design.[PARAGRAPH:2]Urban planning guides orderly development in urban, suburban and rural areas. Although predominantly concerned with the planning of settlements and communities, urban planning is also responsible for the planning and development of water use and resources, rural and agricultural land, parks and conserving areas of natural environmental significance. Practitioners of urban planning are concerned with research and analysis, strategic thinking, architecture, urban design, public consultation, policy recommendations, implementation and management.[PARAGRAPH:2]Urban planners work with the cognate fields of architecture, landscape architecture, civil engineering, and public administration to achieve strategic, policy and sustainability goals. Early urban planners were often members of these cognate fields. Today urban planning is a separate, independent professional discipline. The discipline is the broader category that includes different sub-fields such as land-use planning, zoning, economic development, environmental planning, and transportation planning.
TEXT.Chinese: 城市规划是一个涉及土地开发利用、规划许可、环境保护和利用、公共福利、城市环境设计（包括空气、水）和进出城市地区的基础设施（如交通、通信等）的技术和政治过程，以及分销网络。城市规划又称为城市与区域规划、区域规划、城镇规划、城市规划、农村规划或世界各地的某些组合。它具有多种形式，它可以与城市设计共享观点和实践。〔2〕城市规划指导城市、郊区和农村的有序发展。城市规划虽然主要涉及住区和社区的规划，但也负责规划和开发用水和资源、农村和农业用地、公园和具有自然环境意义的保护区。城市规划的实践者关心研究和分析、战略思维、建筑、城市设计、公众咨询、政策建议、实施和管理。〔2〕城市规划师与建筑、景观建筑、土木工程等相关领域一起工作；以及公共行政以实现战略、政策和可持续性目标。早期的城市规划者常常是这些同源领域的成员。今天，城市规划是一门独立的专业学科。该学科是更广泛的范畴，包括不同的子领域，如土地利用规划、分区、经济发展、环境规划和交通规划。

TEXT.English: Utilizing the now well-developed science of rocketry, the modern exploration of space began in October 1957 when the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1. This tiny satellite orbited the earth for 57 days, providing information on radiation and other phenomena in the upper atmosphere. In less than a year, the United States had also launched a satellite, Explorer 1. This started the "space race", years of competition between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. to achieve new frontiers in space exploration. Space flight advanced rapidly from the simple sub-orbital flights of the 1950s, to manned missions to Earth's moon in the late 1960s. The rapid growth of space technology led to many practical applications, such as weather and surveillance satellites, and vastly improved worldwide communications. Today, although hindered by severe government budget cuts, the exploration of space continues.
TEXT.Chinese: 利用现在发展良好的火箭科学，现代太空探索始于1957年10月苏联发射人造卫星1号。这颗小卫星绕地球运行了57天，提供了高层大气辐射和其他现象的信息。在不到一年的时间里，美国还发射了一颗卫星，探索者1号。这就开始了“太空竞赛”，即美国和苏联多年来为实现太空探索的新前沿而展开的竞争。空间飞行从20世纪50年代的简单亚轨道飞行迅速发展到20世纪60年代末的载人登月任务，空间技术的迅速发展带动了气象卫星、监视卫星等许多实际应用，极大地改善了全球通信。今天，尽管受到政府预算大幅削减的阻碍，太空探索仍在继续。
